[{'created': '2018-05-18 14:14:20.000000000', 'message': "Stringify instance UUID

oslo.versionedobjects merged a patch [1] resulting in the referenced
bug. A second patch [2] was merged that was supposed to fix the issue.
If coerce's value arg is a unicode string, then the method will return
unicode [3]. Subsequent checks for isinstance(str) [4] will fail and a
TypeError will be raised trying to handle the uuid as an int in the
else block. This change ensures that the uuid is an instance of str so
that it is handled properly. This problem was fixed in pypowervm 1.1.15
[5] and the minimum version was bumped for master. However, we can't
backport the pypowervm requirements bump to the stable branches so we
have to fix it here.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/559815/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/561674/
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/561674/2/oslo_versionedobjects/fields.py@367
[4] https://github.com/powervm/pypowervm/blob/1.1.10/pypowervm/utils/uuid.py#L50-L56
[5] https://github.com/powervm/pypowervm/commit/d55b4c84

Change-Id: I1baef962b4b8074f3f9b9ad5402970edc9a3a776

commit_message:
Stringify instance UUID

oslo.versionedobjects merged a patch [1] resulting in the referenced
bug. A second patch [2] was merged that was supposed to fix the issue.
If coerce's value arg is a unicode string, then the method will return
unicode [3]. Subsequent checks for isinstance(str) [4] will fail and a
TypeError will be raised trying to handle the uuid as an int in the
else block. This change ensures that the uuid is an instance of str so
that it is handled properly. This problem was fixed in pypowervm 1.1.15
[5] and the minimum version was bumped for master. However, we can't
backport the pypowervm requirements bump to the stable branches so we
have to fix it here.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/559815/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/561674/
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/561674/2/oslo_versionedobjects/fields.py@367
[4] https://github.com/powervm/pypowervm/blob/1.1.10/pypowervm/utils/uuid.py#L50-L56
[5] https://github.com/powervm/pypowervm/commit/d55b4c84

Change-Id: I1baef962b4b8074f3f9b9ad5402970edc9a3a776
Related-Bug: #1766692
(cherry picked from commit 2386e015ef702ae8db29e396e436a9e293df8f3b)

commit_message:
Use upper constraints when installing ARA

Currently lint tests are failing due to ARA bringing in
extra packages unconstrained. Here we ensure that the
upper constraints are applied when installing ARA.

Change-Id: I35e3688ae632d5f7747f32dafc41d23883c033c5
(cherry picked from commit 2516484ffc5339e2d52dc1dc683804e30e21c162)

commit_message:
Remove -U from pip install

We install packages twice, the -U for pip install will update requirements
to newer versions and might download even an older versions. Remove it.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/554297
Change-Id: I612a5e575da78b7921c45250a5579fcd2fd7d76f

Add test-case for OSM implementation via Trigger-based

Change-Id: I74b91d86d3161aebefb9ad0074a5c6b14782b2ce
Implements: blueprint designate-rolling-upgrade

commit_message:
Using Trigger-based to implemete OSM code-base

This is a solution to upgrade Database schema without downtime.

Work items including:
- implemeting new repos:
  + expand_repo
  + contract_repo
  + data_migration_repo
- Add check version method before upgrade
- Add docs:
  + Designate OSM solution
  + Migration instruction

Change-Id: I3d593124c6b487981d7f735206b19a2cbbe9140e
Implements: blueprint designate-rolling-upgrade

> This is too expensive for a negative test. We can't create 2
 > servers and one volume for a single negative test, especially on a
 > feature that has been here for years without known bugs. It's not
 > worth it.
 > 
 > You can resubmit your patch in the Cinder repo, as a functional
 > test, if you feel it's really needed.

Hi Jordan,now the cost time is 21s,I think the time is also decide by openstack environment.Sometimes the time can be decrease.
2017-04-26 03:09:47.341353 | {2} tempest.api.compute.volumes.test_attach_volume_negative.AttachVolumeNegativeTest.test_server_attach_volume_in_use [21.377037s] ... ok

the negative test above is not equal to normal negative test,I prefer to regard it as integrated test .
refer to time,the negative test below cost more time
2017-04-25 15:50:58.862108 | {0} tempest.api.compute.servers.test_server_rescue_negative.ServerRescueNegativeTestJSON.test_rescued_vm_detach_volume [31.377704s] ... ok"}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2017-04-26 05:40:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

I think this shouldn't be a negative test.
In fact, "one volume can be attached to more than one server" is not a bug, on the contrary, more and more cloud vendors
will support it (moreever, our production cloud already supports it), because it's a useful scenario. We can't use a negative
test to forbid openstack supporting it.'}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-04-26 05:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> I think this shouldn't be a negative test.
 > In fact, "one volume can be attached to more than one server" is
 > not a bug, on the contrary, more and more cloud vendors
 > will support it (moreever, our production cloud already supports
 > it), because it's a useful scenario. We can't use a negative
 > test to forbid openstack supporting it.

Hi zhufl, thanks for your review,"one volume can be attached to more than one server" is not suit for the openstack community.

In my company,some cloud environment is support "one volume can be attached to more than one server",it is due to the developer modify the code of cinder from community.

So I think add the test in tempest have no problem.'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2017-04-26 06:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

hi Liang, now openstack DOESN'T support "one volume can be attached to more than one server", but that doesn't mean openstack SHOULDN'T
support this function.
Tempest will be used in production cloud testing, so if the test fails because one cloud supports this function, that's not reasonable.'}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-04-26 06:31:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> hi Liang, now openstack DOESN'T support "one volume can be attached
 > to more than one server", but that doesn't mean openstack SHOULDN'T
 > support this function.
 > Tempest will be used in production cloud testing, so if the test
 > fails because one cloud supports this function, that's not
 > reasonable.

hi zhufl,thanks,I understand your meaning.
Bug I think tempest is service for openstack community,not for our own cloud environment,if not there are two many tests is not suit.

Sorry I really can't agree with this.
In our production cloud, "one volume attach to more than one server" is already supported (This obvious cannot be deemed as a bug),
and our customers will usually demmand we pass the Tempest and Refstack test(e.g., VimpelCom Russia), so, if this testcase fails,
it's hard for us to give an explaination (we can explain, but it will not be so perfect).

Besids, openstack DOESN'T support a function, not necessary mean openstack SHOULDN't support a function, so, it's meaningless to
put a negative test in Tempest only to ensure openstack DOESN'T support a function. 
We should use negative tests to test those SHOULDN'T appear in openstack, e.g., test_delete_attached_volume'}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-04-27 04:54:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-04-27 05:00:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-04-27 05:10:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2017-04-27 05:14:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

Hello Ghanshyam Mann,at first I not add the config option. 
But the bp of multi-attach have been propose https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:bp/multi-attach-volume,
so I add the config option to "meet the multi-attach-volume in the future". 
If the config option is unnecessiary,I can remove.'}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2017-05-24 12:41:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

@zhufl: multi-attach is not available upstream, so the fact that your cloud supports it does not mean we should allow for it in the integration test suite. If an operator deviates from OpenStack upstream and want to use Tempest for validation, it's up to them to skip any test that might not work for them. So I think a config option here is not justified until the upstream feature is available and we write positive tests for it (as gmann said).

@cloud-liang: I think this test just takes too many resources as an integration test just to validate a return code (see my comment on patch-set #6)."}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-05-24 13:06:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

till then we should wait for this test which can block the feature implementation.'}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-12-09 13:59:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-12-10 01:27:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 21.'}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-12-10 02:45:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-12-10 06:16:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 21897, 'date': '2017-12-10 09:13:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

def attach_volume(self, server, volume, device=None, check_reserved=False):
    """Attaches volume to server and waits for 'in-use' volume status.
    The volume will be detached when the test tears down."""
	self.addCleanup(waiters.wait_for_volume_resource_status,
                    self.volumes_client, volume['id'], 'available')
        self.addCleanup(self._detach_volume, server, volume)'}, {'account_id': 27385, 'date': '2018-02-03 11:48:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-02-06 06:42:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Allow to rebuild arbitrary images

Patch allows to rebuild arbitrary images, which location, filename and
sha256sum are specified in variables, not only hardcoded $DIB_RELEASE/current.

Change-Id: I05418932a0c40d885fe00a49f1f49d7e86c67518

commit_message:
Pin cmd2 to the last python2 version of the library

The cmd2-0.9.0 is python3-only and the rally venv is built
unconstrained, so it's trying to bring in the latest version
which is incompatible with python2. We pin the library to
ensure that the venv build completes correctly.

We also re-arrange the package list to be alphabetically
sorted.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/570879
Change-Id: I1e259ce98fc8517c0cd00a04d6fe7b3f0703f5b4
(cherry picked from commit 5b964963998dbac029bd7c0b1a6e87eb4a2c28ac)

commit_message:
Remove keystone_authtoken section for aodh

1. Now, the aodh use [service_credentials] to get credentials[0],
remove the unused [keystone_authtoken]
2. Move memcache stuff into service_credentials section

refer to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/570393/

Change-Id: I08cf3ec4e9ca32cc83d74bd4204e7e170b01feb7

subject: Use iniset to populate CEPH_CONF_FILE whenever possible
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4523, 'name': 'Eric Harney', 'email': 'eharney@redhat.com', 'username': 'eharney'}, {'_account_id': 6984, 'name': 'Sébastien Han', 'email': 'seb@redhat.com', 'username': 'leseb'}, {'_account_id': 8056, 'name': 'Ramana Raja', 'email': 'rraja@redhat.com', 'username': 'Ram_Raja'}, {'_account_id': 9003, 'name': 'Tom Barron', 'email': 'tpb@dyncloud.net', 'username': 'tbarron'}, {'_account_id': 9236, 'name': 'Jon Bernard', 'email': 'jobernar@redhat.com', 'username': 'jbernard'}, {'_account_id': 10459, 'name': 'Luigi Toscano', 'email': 'ltoscano@redhat.com', 'username': 'ltoscano'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-05-22 16:39:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-05-22 16:42:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Please note that re-running this may not work, because iniset does not handle the rewriting of a variable when the key contains a space. I sent a review for devstack:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/570000/

I did not put a Depends-On on purpose: the basic case (run devstack once) should not be impacted. If you want, I can add Depends-On (or feel free to edit it).'}, {'account_id': 8056, 'date': '2018-05-23 10:28:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Please note that re-running this may not work, because iniset does not handle the rewriting of a variable when the key contains a space. I sent a review for devstack: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/570000/

A ceph conf option with spaces in between is equivalent to one with underscores instead, e.g., 'osd journal size' is same as 'osd_journal_size'."}, {'account_id': 8056, 'date': '2018-05-23 10:53:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8056, 'date': '2018-05-23 11:04:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2018-05-23 14:40:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

So if you make Ramana's change (replace spaces with underscores for ceph options) then this will work even before your devstack change merges, right?  If so, then please do this.  I run devstack locally."}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-05-29 09:44:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > So if you make Ramana's change (replace spaces with underscores for
 > ceph options) then this will work even before your devstack change
 > merges, right?  If so, then please do this.  I run devstack
 > locally.

Please note that the code works if you run unstack.sh before executing stack.sh again. I'm not sure that re-running stack.sh again without unstack.sh is supported; if it is not, the devstack change is not a concern for the current code, which *right now* only writes keys which do not exist already. 
tl;dr I think the patch can be merged as it is if we the normal workflow is ./unstack.sh && ./stack.sh


If I replace the spaces with underscores in the keys, yes, of course everything will work. But the ceph documentation really uses the space versions, and the deployer tool should support it, not the other way around :)"}, {'account_id': 8056, 'date': '2018-05-29 10:08:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2018-05-29 15:25:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

> I think the patch can be merged as it is if we the normal workflow is ./unstack.sh && ./stack.sh

Makes sense to me then, thanks!'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-22 16:39:41.000000000', 'message': 'Use iniset to populate CEPH_CONF_FILE whenever possible

The remaining occurrences of cat <<... EOF populate non-INI files.

Remove few security checks which are not needed, because iniset
takes care of checking the existence of the section and keys and
adding or replacing them if needed.

Change-Id: I4951e1f2f456b3c6f83fd4868db90fae9d811fbe
'}]
commit_message:
Use iniset to populate CEPH_CONF_FILE whenever possible

The remaining occurrences of cat <<... EOF populate non-INI files.

Remove few security checks which are not needed, because iniset
takes care of checking the existence of the section and keys and
adding or replacing them if needed.

Change-Id: I4951e1f2f456b3c6f83fd4868db90fae9d811fbe

Switch to stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1] stestr is
maintained project to which all Openstack projects
should migrate.
Let's switch it then.

[{'created': '2017-09-26 02:05:00.000000000', 'message': 'TrivialFix: Correct reST field lists in docstrings

Most common format for documenting arguments is reST field, the incorrect
docstring will cause a Sphinx warning to be generated and caused the documentation
to be improperly rendered.

[1] http://sphinx-doc.org/domains.html#info-field-lists

The old patch will be abandon: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/490432/

Change-Id: Icd84ad664dad2ea116864735dbaf388d1774c42a
'}]
commit_message:
TrivialFix: Correct reST field lists in docstrings

Most common format for documenting arguments is reST field, the incorrect
docstring will cause a Sphinx warning to be generated and caused the documentation
to be improperly rendered.

[1] http://sphinx-doc.org/domains.html#info-field-lists

The old patch will be abandon: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/490432/

Change-Id: Icd84ad664dad2ea116864735dbaf388d1774c42a

commit_message:
update "auth_url" in install docs

Based on the change in Keystone Install Guide [1],
this patch replace port 35357 with 5000 for "auth_port" in docs.
for more details,please see [2]

[1]https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/install/keystone-install-rdo.html#install-and-configure-components
[2]https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/contributor/http-api.html

Change-Id: I67a337b75dd6e694ba23f8dd630835f706d2dc55

commit_message:
Allow to check pep8 along with D000

This patch only setup package dependency which named Pygments
for this test. Pygments also exist item in lower-contraints.txt
which does not setup along with tox env.

Change-Id: I1a75150b7fd813a4126716b898a55f35c64c5ec6

- docker driver add start/stop operation
- profile fix create the container not running
- profile add handle stop operation

commit_message:
Disallow multiattach for encrypted volumes

We can't assume that the LUKS layer used for
volume encryption functions in a way that will
safely work with multiattach.

Closes-Bug: #1770689

Change-Id: I613b48a9e89270b2f0266bffc5aeeefad37ce8fb
(cherry picked from commit 18327971ca7231807294a6b1dbf3d80c23cb6796)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-20 19:31:32.000000000', 'message': "Log a warning and add nova-status check for old API service versions

Change Ib984c30543acb3ca9cb95fb53d44d9ded0f5a5c8, which was added
in Newton when cells v2 was optional, added some transitional code
to the API for looking up an instance, which didn't rely on instance
mappings in a cell to find the instance if the minimum nova-osapi_compute
service version was from before Ocata.

People have reported this being a source of confusion when upgrading
from before Ocata, when cells v2 wasn't required, to Ocata+ where cells
v2 along with the mapping setup is required. That's because they might
have older nova-osapi_compute service version records in their 'nova'
(cell) database which makes the API think the code is older than it
actually is, and results in an InstanceNotFound error.

This change does two things:

1. Adds a warning to the compute API code in this scenario to serve
   as a breadcrumb if a deployment hits this issue.

2. A nova-status check to look for minimum nova-osapi_compute service
   versions across all cells and report the issue as a warning. It's
   not an upgrade failure since we don't know how the nova-api service
   is configured, but leave that investigation up to the deployer.

This is also written in such a way that we should be able to backport
this through to stable/ocata.

Conflicts:
      doc/source/cli/nova-status.rst

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is because the Rocky section
in the man page does not exist in Queens. The note about
the new check is added to the Queens section and mentions
it was backported from Rocky.

Change-Id: Ie2bc4616439352850cf29a9de7d33a06c8f7c2b8
Closes-Bug: #1759316
(cherry picked from commit eaf6340847c35ace3b4b681a95b8a79a7a3f2491)
"}]
commit_message:
Log a warning and add nova-status check for old API service versions

Change Ib984c30543acb3ca9cb95fb53d44d9ded0f5a5c8, which was added
in Newton when cells v2 was optional, added some transitional code
to the API for looking up an instance, which didn't rely on instance
mappings in a cell to find the instance if the minimum nova-osapi_compute
service version was from before Ocata.

People have reported this being a source of confusion when upgrading
from before Ocata, when cells v2 wasn't required, to Ocata+ where cells
v2 along with the mapping setup is required. That's because they might
have older nova-osapi_compute service version records in their 'nova'
(cell) database which makes the API think the code is older than it
actually is, and results in an InstanceNotFound error.

This change does two things:

1. Adds a warning to the compute API code in this scenario to serve
   as a breadcrumb if a deployment hits this issue.

2. A nova-status check to look for minimum nova-osapi_compute service
   versions across all cells and report the issue as a warning. It's
   not an upgrade failure since we don't know how the nova-api service
   is configured, but leave that investigation up to the deployer.

This is also written in such a way that we should be able to backport
this through to stable/ocata.

Conflicts:
      doc/source/cli/nova-status.rst

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is because the Rocky section
in the man page does not exist in Queens. The note about
the new check is added to the Queens section and mentions
it was backported from Rocky.

Change-Id: Ie2bc4616439352850cf29a9de7d33a06c8f7c2b8
Closes-Bug: #1759316
(cherry picked from commit eaf6340847c35ace3b4b681a95b8a79a7a3f2491)

commit_message:
Add nova-status check for ironic flavor migration

In Pike we started requiring that ironic instances have their
embedded flavor migrated to track the ironic node custom
resource class. This can be done either via the normal running
of the nova-compute service and ironic driver or via the
'nova-manage db ironic_flavor_migration' command.

This change adds a nova-status check to see if there are any
unmigrated ironic instances across all non-cell0 cells, and
is based mostly on the same logic within the nova-manage command
except it's multi-cell aware and doesn't use the objects.

Conflicts:
      doc/source/cli/nova-status.rst

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is because the Rocky section
in the man page does not exist in Queens. The note about
the new check is added to the Queens section and mentions
it was backported from Rocky.

Change-Id: Ifd22325e849db2353b1b1eedfe998e3d6a79591c
(cherry picked from commit 7eb670352126ed8d30426eb422fe5aed9cb21e7f)

commit_message:
Improve performance when list instances with IP filter

When list instances with IP filter, there is no need
to try to get instances from BuildRequest, as building
instances will not have IP address. Skip this db call
can slightly improve performance.

Closes-Bug: #1764685

Change-Id: Ic02206e887e3fea7752d615bbed680510c482097
(cherry picked from commit a3a94cf4ec3c0e41ab2a8a66dfc0e7adca2d2a8e)

CI tests frequently teardown by rolling back interface
attachments and then deleting the server, both of which
are asynchronous. If we're trying to detach an interface
on a guest that is gone, we don't need to log a traceback
exception in the logs, just let the InstanceNotFound
raise up to the ComputeManager which will handle the
error and log it appropriately.

commit_message:
xenapi: handle InstanceNotFound in detach_interface()

CI tests frequently teardown by rolling back interface
attachments and then deleting the server, both of which
are asynchronous. If we're trying to detach an interface
on a guest that is gone, we don't need to log a traceback
exception in the logs, just let the InstanceNotFound
raise up to the ComputeManager which will handle the
error and log it appropriately.

Change-Id: I9428be0e6e5b640fdda00410817925001361fd2c
Closes-Bug: #1759979
(cherry picked from commit 5a42701f89a5139acdc38f8572b1083ba528264c)

Add random sleep between retry calls to placement

Attempt to reduce the resource provider contention by adding a random
sleep between retry calls to placement.

commit_message:
Pin cmd2 to the last python2 version of the library

The cmd2-0.9.0 is python3-only and the rally venv is built
unconstrained, so it's trying to bring in the latest version
which is incompatible with python2. We pin the library to
ensure that the venv build completes correctly.

We also re-arrange the package list to be alphabetically
sorted.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/570879
Change-Id: I1e259ce98fc8517c0cd00a04d6fe7b3f0703f5b4

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-15 16:55:21.000000000', 'message': 'Don't reschedule on RequestedVRamTooHigh errors

The libvirt driver validates the hw_video_ram image property,
if specified, and the flavor extra spec "hw_video:ram_max_mb"
is set. If validation fails, the libvirt driver raises
RequestedVRamTooHigh which is not handled explicitly in
ComputeManager._build_and_run_instance so it will result in
a RescheduledException to another compute to retry the spawn
but that will always fail because this isn't something that
is per-compute host.

This change adds the error handling in _build_and_run_instance
so that we'll fail and abort the build and not reschedule.

Long-term, this validation should be moved into the API code
since it's not specific to a compute host and would be user
error that should result in a 400 response.

Change-Id: I93b409ca2b7b36400759ee9d2cd5b71c6df186ab
Partial-Bug: #1770726
(cherry picked from commit cd53a181be22291e6f9be1430cab12ba1f381b8a)
'}]
commit_message:
Don't reschedule on RequestedVRamTooHigh errors

The libvirt driver validates the hw_video_ram image property,
if specified, and the flavor extra spec "hw_video:ram_max_mb"
is set. If validation fails, the libvirt driver raises
RequestedVRamTooHigh which is not handled explicitly in
ComputeManager._build_and_run_instance so it will result in
a RescheduledException to another compute to retry the spawn
but that will always fail because this isn't something that
is per-compute host.

This change adds the error handling in _build_and_run_instance
so that we'll fail and abort the build and not reschedule.

Long-term, this validation should be moved into the API code
since it's not specific to a compute host and would be user
error that should result in a 400 response.

Change-Id: I93b409ca2b7b36400759ee9d2cd5b71c6df186ab
Partial-Bug: #1770726
(cherry picked from commit cd53a181be22291e6f9be1430cab12ba1f381b8a)

commit_message:
Add ssbd and virt-ssbd flags to cpu_model_extra_flags whitelist

This adds two other flags to the whitelist of available options to
the cpu_model_extra_flags variable related to further variants of
Meltdown/Spectre recently published.

Related-Bug: #1750829
Change-Id: I72085016c8756ff88a4da722368f62359bcd7080
(cherry picked from commit a27ea0f9100d0061c1cf3b20407095d3cd04df26)

commit_message:
Cap cmd2 to < 0.9.0

cmd2>=0.9.0 now require python3.4 or greater. We install ansible under
python2 (for now) so we need to cap the cmd2 install to make the ansible
installation function.

Upstream bug at https://github.com/python-cmd2/cmd2/issues/421

Change-Id: I5ec830e092646a3626cacea264de9ad81fcdd124

commit_message:
Add dib-utils to aclfixer.py exception list

diskimage-builder and dib-utils share the same ACL file, so both
need to be on the exception list otherwise the diskimage-builder ACL
will be touched by aclfixer.py.

Change-Id: I85f16eea5312277ccb2c7cd7e32838dd2ae91d16

Add aclfixer tool to generate ACL fixes patches

aclfixer can be used to remove tagging / branch creating
rights for official OpenStack deliverables.

It maintains a list of standing exceptions to the rule.

commit_message:
[TEST] Disable developer mode for tempest

Given that tempest is in upper-constraints and its releases
are published to pip, we don't need to use developer mode
for our tests. Given that we're not really in a position
to closely track every move the QA team makes, perhaps it
makes better sense for us to just used the released versions
for our tests so that we only have to deal with those changes
whenever they release, implying the confidence that they have
completed their implementation changes.

Change-Id: I7f168e738354012d807db836203ed04749dbe854

commit_message:
Use upper constraints when installing ARA

Currently lint tests are failing due to ARA bringing in
extra packages unconstrained. Here we ensure that the
upper constraints are applied when installing ARA.

Change-Id: I35e3688ae632d5f7747f32dafc41d23883c033c5

subject: Make sure 'replicas' option is configurable

Change-Id: Ifc05bd2e08e7f3fe115ca14c722fb23b6a853481

commit_message:
Make sure 'replicas' option is configurable

The set of kubernetes replicas in '/etc/qinling/qinling.conf' will
make the set of replicas in 'qinling/config.py' lose efficacy.

Change-Id: Ifc05bd2e08e7f3fe115ca14c722fb23b6a853481

messages:
[{'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-05-18 15:13:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2018-05-18 16:37:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

As I recall the rationale for the initial commit only allowing "pcid" was to make it backportable because we didn't want to make it open-ended in the stable branches.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-05-18 17:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with check hyper-v

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com//nova/569442/1/ : FAILURE in 1h 46m 10s'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-05-20 21:59:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The reason we added that limitation was so the PCID fix could be backported, removing it on stable branches isn't appropriate"}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-05-21 22:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> As I recall the rationale for the initial commit only allowing
 > "pcid" was to make it backportable because we didn't want to make
 > it open-ended in the stable branches.

Yes, that was indeed the initial rationale.  Meanwhile ... enter the just-announced CVE (that is based on Spectre/Meltdown):

    "Speculative Store Buffer Bypass"[0][1][2]

To mitigate this new CVE, we now need to expose yet another Intel CPU flag to the guest -- 'ssbd' ("Speculative Store Bypass Disable")

Instead of white-listing this new CPU feature flag ('ssbd'), we simply lift the restriction on the flags.

[0] https://bugs.chromium.org/p/project-zero/issues/detail?id=1528
[1] https://access.redhat.com/security/vulnerabilities/ssbd
[2] https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2018-3639'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-05-21 22:26:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > As I recall the rationale for the initial commit only allowing
 > > "pcid" was to make it backportable because we didn't want to make
 > > it open-ended in the stable branches.
 > 
 > Yes, that was indeed the initial rationale.  Meanwhile ... enter
 > the just-announced CVE (that is based on Spectre/Meltdown):
 > 
 > "Speculative Store Buffer Bypass"[0][1][2]
 > 
 > To mitigate this new CVE, we now need to expose yet another Intel
 > CPU flag to the guest -- 'ssbd' ("Speculative Store Bypass
 > Disable")

The above is the reason why we need to backport this restriction-lifting Nova patch from Rocky.  Or ... we can again open up the debate of whether we want to add this new CPU flag ('ssdb') to the existing white list (currently of: 'pcid') for stable branches.

[...]'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-05-22 05:09:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Adding ssdb to the whitelist is what we should do here.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-05-22 07:06:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Adding ssdb to the whitelist is what we should do here.

Okay.  (Could have avoided this madness if we didn't enforce the silly restriction in the first place.  But whatever.)"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-05-22 13:43:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Okay.  (Could have avoided this madness if we didn't enforce the
 > silly restriction in the first place.  But whatever.)

The other way to look at it is that if we had done the original plan for stable, you'd be having to add another workaround flag for this issue too. The whitelist for stable was the compromise we settled on, and now we're able to easily add something to that list instead of something more heavyweight."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-05-22 13:48:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Adding ssdb to the whitelist is what we should do here.

Agree.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-05-22 15:12:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > Adding ssdb to the whitelist is what we should do here.
 > 
 > Agree.

Okay, seems like people are piling on.  It's quicker than arguing.

 > > Adding ssdb to the whitelist is what we should do here.
 > 
 > Agree.

Hang on.

There is even better reason to not restrict because, for AMD Compute nodes, we have to allow yet another CPU flag[1], called "virt-ssdb":

    Some AMD processors only support a non-architectural means of
    enabling Speculative Store Bypass Disable. To allow simplified
    handling in virtual environments, hypervisors will expose an
    architectural definition through CPUID bit 0x80000008_EBX[25].  This 
    needs to be exposed to guest OS running on AMD x86 hosts to allow
    them to protect against CVE-2018-3639.

    Note that since this CPUID bit won't be present in the host CPUID
    results on physical hosts, it will not be enabled automatically in
    guests configured with "host-model" CPU unless using QEMU version >=
    2.9.0. Thus for older versions of QEMU, this feature must be 
    manually enabled using policy=force.  Guests using the
    "host-passthrough" CPU mode do not need special handling.



[1] https://www.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2018-May/msg01562.html'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-05-22 15:37:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> There is even better reason to not restrict because, for AMD
 > Compute nodes, we have to allow yet another CPU flag[1], called
 > "virt-ssdb":

That can go in the list as well.'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2018-05-22 16:07:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I've read through the context to this. I understand the concern around setting a precedent backporting features here, but I personally don't think it's pragmatic to enforce it in this case. To explain, I can't think of a situation where a user can abuse this feature to interfere with a feature of *Nova* introduced prior to the merging of this feature in to master. That is, while it allows users to enable CPU features other than those directly related to Spectre/Meltdown, this doesn't impact Nova.

The other reason is that Spectre/Meltdown represented a new class of vulnerability, and we always expected a steady trickle of new specific vulnerabilities in this class. Case in point, as already noted 'ssdb' is already out of date, as we now additionally need 'virt-ssdb' for AMD cpus. I won't be surprised to see a couple more of these over the next year or so, and I can't personally see any advantage in requiring stable users to wait for us to add to the whitelist before they can deploy fixes. Also note that these have been, and will presumably continue to be, embargoed vulnerabilities, which leaves us a limited amount of time to assess, review, and patch. In fact, I suspect that we'll find upstream stable users independently making these patches manually as they arise, which is what stable is supposed to be for.

So while I do understand that we don't want to set a precedent around backporting features, I think this would be a pragmatic and user-friendly exception. Any feature enablement is strictly a side-effect of a bugfix.

Downstream we've decided to backport this anyway, so pragmatically we're not going to be putting effort into keeping the whitelist up to date in upstream stable."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-05-22 18:16:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

We can add more things to the list of choices on stable branches as they arise, -2 otherwise; we don't really need to continue debating this."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-05-22 18:28:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

FWIW, I thought we had discussed this originally for the 'pcid' flag and agreed with the whitelist approach for stable as a compromise to enable operators to mitigate issues from the spectre/meltdown updates. I think the reasonable thing to do here is to extend the whitelist on stable with the relevant flags when needed."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-05-22 21:49:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

Thanks for the clarification.

I agree with Matt and Dan here I know it feels uncomfortable but the whitelist is the right way to fix this on stable branches'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2018-05-23 08:24:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> FWIW, I thought we had discussed this originally for the 'pcid'
 > flag and agreed with the whitelist approach for stable as a
 > compromise to enable operators to mitigate issues from the
 > spectre/meltdown updates.

I read this discussion. It was my understanding, and please correct me if I'm wrong because I couldn't find anything else written down, that the reason we went with a whitelist rather than what later merged in master was to avoid setting a precedent around backporting 'features' to stable. That is, it was to make a point rather than specifically for technical reasons. As I said earlier I understand that, but I think the case for waiving it in this particular instance is stronger. If there were technical concerns raised I'd be very interested to understand them, especially as we have decided to remove the whitelist downstream.

 > I think the reasonable thing to do here
 > is to extend the whitelist on stable with the relevant flags when
 > needed.

That's fine, but given that we've gone in a simpler direction downstream you should be looking for somebody else to step up to do that work, and to stay on top of it going forward."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-05-23 13:37:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > FWIW, I thought we had discussed this originally for the 'pcid'
 > > flag and agreed with the whitelist approach for stable as a
 > > compromise to enable operators to mitigate issues from the
 > > spectre/meltdown updates.
 > 
 > I read this discussion. It was my understanding, and please correct
 > me if I'm wrong because I couldn't find anything else written down,
 > that the reason we went with a whitelist rather than what later
 > merged in master was to avoid setting a precedent around
 > backporting 'features' to stable. That is, it was to make a point
 > rather than specifically for technical reasons. As I said earlier I
 > understand that, but I think the case for waiving it in this
 > particular instance is stronger. If there were technical concerns
 > raised I'd be very interested to understand them, especially as we
 > have decided to remove the whitelist downstream.

We went with a whitelist on stable to adhere to stable branch policy (documented here [1]) with the highlight being that stable branches aim is to be a safe, stable source for past releases. New features and backward incompatible changes are not allowed on stable branches. Enabling CPU feature flags across the board definitely violates the stable branch policy, but we arrived at a compromise to enable only the flag necessary to mitigate the meltdown/spectre update performance degradation because it's significant (up to 30% performance degradation).

Downstream, we don't have a stable branch policy, and that's fine, but upstream we do.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html

 > 
 > > I think the reasonable thing to do here
 > > is to extend the whitelist on stable with the relevant flags when
 > > needed.
 > 
 > That's fine, but given that we've gone in a simpler direction
 > downstream you should be looking for somebody else to step up to do
 > that work, and to stay on top of it going forward.

There are several people who are happy to do the work, including myself, but we were not informed about this issue, and thus weren't able to do the work this time. Next time, I recommend reaching out to those who were originally involved in the upstream fix and stable branch backports to allow them to work on fixes that will fit in with upstream stable branch policy."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-05-23 23:34:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Here is the change that adds the sspd and virt-sspd choices to the option:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/570271/'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-05-29 10:32:45.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-05-29 10:37:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Abandoned

I still maintain that forced decision to land that Queens backport is utterly wrong.  Although that ship has sailed, for the record, here is why I think that was a wrong decision:

If / when in the near future Intel and AMD introduce more flags for yet more CVEs: Upstream has to respin another patch.  All downstream distributions should backport that.  Test it.  Make RPM / 'deb' builds.  Release Engineering work.  Customer errata.  Documentation.  Support Teams will have to deal with tickets.  Now _all_ deployers need to upgrade Nova packages yet again.

No one seems to have given a thought to the above."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-18 15:13:28.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Lift the restriction of choices for `cpu_model_extra_flags`

Commit 6b601b7 (libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags)
added support for allowing to specify individual CPU feature flags, but
restricted the options only to "PCID" (refer to its commit message for
why).

In this change we lift the restriction of choices, and allow to specify
multiple CPU feature flags for all three CPU modes for the libvirt
driver: 'custom', 'host-model', and 'host-passthrough'.

For example:

     [libvirt]
     cpu_mode = custom
     cpu_model = IvyBridge
     cpu_model_extra_flags = pcid, vmx, pdpe1gb

This will allow additional use cases such as:

  - Ability to use 1GB huge pages with models that don't provide it
    (such as Intel "Haswell" variants) as one use case for extra flags:

        cpu_mode = custom
        cpu_model = Haswell-noTSX-IBRS
        cpu_model_extra_flags = pdpe1gb

  - Nested Virtualization -- an operator can specify the Intel 'vmx' (or
    AMD 'svm') flags for the level-1 Nova guest CPU models.  (Assuming
    the 'nested' flag is enabled on the level-0 / bare-metal kernel.)

(A future Nova patch will also allow ability to remove CPU flags.)

Closes-Bug: #1750829
Change-Id: I9a862619f379057bb48cb85a84dfc50d763030a6
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit cc27a2007f314df18812d54a087f6192d6aed3fb)
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Lift the restriction of choices for `cpu_model_extra_flags`

Commit 6b601b7 (libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags)
added support for allowing to specify individual CPU feature flags, but
restricted the options only to "PCID" (refer to its commit message for
why).

In this change we lift the restriction of choices, and allow to specify
multiple CPU feature flags for all three CPU modes for the libvirt
driver: 'custom', 'host-model', and 'host-passthrough'.

For example:

     [libvirt]
     cpu_mode = custom
     cpu_model = IvyBridge
     cpu_model_extra_flags = pcid, vmx, pdpe1gb

This will allow additional use cases such as:

  - Ability to use 1GB huge pages with models that don't provide it
    (such as Intel "Haswell" variants) as one use case for extra flags:

        cpu_mode = custom
        cpu_model = Haswell-noTSX-IBRS
        cpu_model_extra_flags = pdpe1gb

  - Nested Virtualization -- an operator can specify the Intel 'vmx' (or
    AMD 'svm') flags for the level-1 Nova guest CPU models.  (Assuming
    the 'nested' flag is enabled on the level-0 / bare-metal kernel.)

(A future Nova patch will also allow ability to remove CPU flags.)

Closes-Bug: #1750829
Change-Id: I9a862619f379057bb48cb85a84dfc50d763030a6
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit cc27a2007f314df18812d54a087f6192d6aed3fb)

commit_message:
Introduce os_blazar role in gerrit

This commit ensures that the Blazar role passes all tests.

The lint tests are failing, as the password were logged while setting
up Blazar server, so it ensures that they are not logged.

Fixes the functional tests by add the `rabbitmq_all` to infra1 group

Change-Id: Ie20d470d24a97749087a7f99563e8f32648c7a02

This really feels like a list we don't want to have to update every cycle. Can we link to the "latest" versions instead of a series? Can we link to a page that can be built from a template?'}, {'account_id': 14482, 'date': '2018-04-18 16:49:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I think www.o.o pages do not have "latest" part on URL, which would be the reason of specifying queens instead of using latest. Might that having "latest" urls like https://www.openstack.org/software/releases/latest/components/horizon would be a good idea?

 > Can we link to a page that can be built from a template?'}, {'account_id': 20156, 'date': '2018-04-18 17:03:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The install-guide is unversioned, so we should indeed specify when we want to refer to Queens and when to earlier releases, but I don't think we should refer to Rocky from here.

I understand manually maintaining these links calls for automation, but how about if we just get rid of the table altogether and point to https://www.openstack.org/software/ instead? There's a basic diagram there that is helpful."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-18 17:30:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

 > but how about if we just get rid of the table altogether and point
 > to https://www.openstack.org/software/ instead? There's a basic
 > diagram there that is helpful.

I like the idea of just having the info in one place like that and linking to it from here."}, {'account_id': 14482, 'date': '2018-04-19 00:53:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree that referring to Queens is better than Rocky. What if there would be an additional variable to redirect to current latest stable branch (e.g., https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest-stable )?

 > we want to refer to Queens and when to earlier releases, but I

 > to https://www.openstack.org/software/ instead? There's a basic

Or linking to https://www.openstack.org/software/project-navigator would be nice?"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-19 12:59:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I like this idea. I think we even have the variable we need in place already, so someone would just need to add the redirect rules.

That's probably even better, yes.

Good, I like the idea too. At the PTG, we discussed turning the install guide into a versioned document again, so if we do it, then having latest stable redirects will be very helpful."}, {'account_id': 20156, 'date': '2018-05-23 14:56:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 19779, 'date': '2018-05-28 02:01:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17765, 'date': '2018-05-29 08:33:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

lgtm, thx'}]

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6593, 'name': 'Dirk Mueller', 'email': 'dirk@dmllr.de', 'username': 'dmllr'}, {'_account_id': 13294, 'name': 'Javier Peña', 'email': 'jpena@redhat.com', 'username': 'jpena'}, {'_account_id': 13404, 'name': 'Alberto Planas', 'email': 'aplanas@gmail.com', 'username': 'aplanas'}, {'_account_id': 19648, 'name': 'SUSE Cloud CI', 'email': 'dmueller+suse-cloud-ci@suse.de', 'username': 'suse-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 13294, 'date': '2018-05-23 16:49:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13294, 'date': '2018-05-23 17:47:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 13404, 'date': '2018-05-23 17:55:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2018-05-27 15:11:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Imho we should be doing something like 

  %python_expand(
     PYTHON=$python testr...
  )

How many spec files are affected by that issue? When we change the singlespec macros here then we need to upstream that change (this singlespec macros file is just a copy for fedora style packages)'}, {'account_id': 13294, 'date': '2018-05-29 08:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Imho we should be doing something like
 > 
 > %python_expand(
 > PYTHON=$python testr...
 > )
 > 

Actually... you're right, it makes more sense to do it like this. I'll fix the affected specs to include that.

 > How many spec files are affected by that issue? When we change the
 > singlespec macros here then we need to upstream that change (this
 > singlespec macros file is just a copy for fedora style packages)

There's 2 specs affected (oslo.concurrency and oslo.rootwrap). I'll abandon this change and fix it in the spec itself with your proposed approach."}, {'account_id': 13294, 'date': '2018-05-29 08:43:30.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

I'll use an alternate approach in the specs."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-23 16:49:40.000000000', 'message': 'Export PYTHON variable in %python_expand

In some cases (for example the testr configuration in [1]) we expect
a PYTHON environment variable to define the python executable to use,
and default to "python" if none is present.

By explicitly setting the environment variable in the %python_expand
macro, we are avoiding ambiguity and keeping compatibility with
Python 2 and 3.

[1] - https://github.com/openstack/oslo.concurrency/blob/master/.testr.conf#L5

Change-Id: I7d7ba3e546448f64aeaef34e3a447efbcb5523ba
'}, {'created': '2018-05-23 17:47:02.000000000', 'message': 'Export PYTHON variable in %python_expand

In some cases (for example the testr configuration in [1]) we expect
a PYTHON environment variable to define the python executable to use,
and default to "python" if none is present.

By explicitly setting the environment variable in the %python_expand
macro, we are avoiding ambiguity and keeping compatibility with
Python 2 and 3.

[1] - https://github.com/openstack/oslo.concurrency/blob/master/.testr.conf#L5

Change-Id: I7d7ba3e546448f64aeaef34e3a447efbcb5523ba
'}]
commit_message:
Export PYTHON variable in %python_expand

In some cases (for example the testr configuration in [1]) we expect
a PYTHON environment variable to define the python executable to use,
and default to "python" if none is present.

By explicitly setting the environment variable in the %python_expand
macro, we are avoiding ambiguity and keeping compatibility with
Python 2 and 3.

[1] - https://github.com/openstack/oslo.concurrency/blob/master/.testr.conf#L5

Change-Id: I7d7ba3e546448f64aeaef34e3a447efbcb5523ba

commit_message:
Updates documentation section

- Contributor Guide is also a speciality team.
- Since current documents are only published from master branch,
  let's move the order of mentioning stable branch to least.
- Bug report page (Storyboard) for Contributor Guide
- Mentioning retention policy for EOL documents

Change-Id: Ia14cbb5475e91884ad32525af1bf1cde8a21e9c3

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-04 08:14:56.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes port security settings caching issue

When updating the MAC spoofing for a given vswitch port, its
Msvm_EthernetSwitchPortSecuritySettingData object is removed
and a new one is created, but the original object is not
cleared from the cache. Because of this, the next update will
fail with a Not Found exception.

This patch addresses this issue.

Closes-Bug: #1744755

Change-Id: I91b9000c64d269b7d5b1db9e0c6344bbd70e37b2
(cherry picked from commit 776270c4b3be0523f2ee2a73792b4a41bb52d6f5)
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes port security settings caching issue

When updating the MAC spoofing for a given vswitch port, its
Msvm_EthernetSwitchPortSecuritySettingData object is removed
and a new one is created, but the original object is not
cleared from the cache. Because of this, the next update will
fail with a Not Found exception.

This patch addresses this issue.

Closes-Bug: #1744755

Change-Id: I91b9000c64d269b7d5b1db9e0c6344bbd70e37b2
(cherry picked from commit 776270c4b3be0523f2ee2a73792b4a41bb52d6f5)

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

Uncap eventlet to make the local dependency list match the global list
to allow us to add the new lower-constraints.txt file.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I8294a4cf154e28e56acbc3a6d63d743a9c1b1481
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add flag to enable QoS DSCP marking in ODL

In OpenDaylight, a config parameter is available to enable DSCP
marking inheritance for packets egressing out of OVS through
vxlna/gre tunnels.

Add a flag in TripleO to enable this parameter via
puppet-opendaylight.

qos NeutronServicePlugins is needed for this.

Change-Id: Iac3c9d208a57d5ff8f59508e930978eea35978c3

commit_message:
Fix cmd2 release inside requirements

We're hitting problems due to the upgrade of cmd2 happened today.
Without this in place any of the tripleo-quickstart would work, failing
with this message:

cmd2 requires Python '>=3.4' but the running Python is 2.7.5

Any better thinked solution is more than welcome.

Change-Id: I4e2f3648fbd0e69a9ee545b9e458608a998230d2

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

[{'created': '2017-12-08 16:17:37.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for mysql 5.7 on Xenial

Ubuntu is the source of the mysql package for the mysql datastore.
If the datastore is based on Xenial, the code presently pulls the
package from the Trusty repository, so that Xenial gets Trusty level
code.  This is a flawed approach for several reasons including
support and code maintenance.  This patch fixes this problem by
using the native package provided by the distro.  Trusty gets the
5.6 version and Xenial gets the 5.7 version.

Change-Id: I4f4e497208b8f4728580e48239a8ae208e0a96dd

'}, {'created': '2017-12-10 23:31:38.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for Mysql 5.7 on Ubuntu Xenial

Ubuntu is the source of the mysql package for the Ubuntu based
mysql datastore.  If the base O/S is Xenial, the code presently
pulls the package from the Trusty repository resulting in an
unsupported Ubuntu configuration that is composed of Trusty and
Xenial code.  This patch fixes this problem by using the proper
repositories as defined by Ubuntu.  The result is that Trusty
gets the 5.6 version of mysql and Xenial gets the 5.7 version.

Note Xenial does not provide the 5.6 version of mysql.

The size of the root file system is increased from 3 to 4 GBs
as the Mysql Xenial image does not fit in 3 GBs. This has an
impact on the flavors that are used by Trove for testing. This
impacts the database specific test configuration files as the
size of the root file system is included in the name of the
flavor. For example, the old flavor test.tiny-3 becomes
test.tiny-4 as the root file system space is increased from 3
GBs to 4. The memory size is slightly incremented as well.

Change-Id: I4f4e497208b8f4728580e48239a8ae208e0a96dd
'}, {'created': '2018-01-05 00:09:49.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for MySQL 5.7 on Ubuntu Xenial

Ubuntu Trusty continues to get MySQL 5.6.

The selection of the MySQL version is based on the version
of Ubuntu that is installed.  If the script trovestack is
invoked on Xenial, the version that is chosen is 5.7.  If
it is invoked on Trusty, then version 5.6 is chosen.

The only thing that is eliminated is the dubious combination
of MySQL 5.6 on Ubuntu Xenial.  This combination is probably
not supported by Ubuntu as it is down level from their
standard offering is probably not tested anywhere.

Note Xenial does not provide the 5.6 version of mysql.  This
was accomplished by initializing the Apt repo with the
Trusty software repository.

The size of the root file system is increased from 3 to 4 GBs
as the Mysql Xenial image does not fit in 3 GBs. This has an
impact on the flavors that are used by Trove for testing as the
name of the flavor includes the size of the root file system.

This is turn caused a change to each of the db specific test
config files as the trove falvors are referenced in them.

Change-Id: I4f4e497208b8f4728580e48239a8ae208e0a96dd

commit_message:
Add support for MySQL 5.7 on Ubuntu Xenial

Ubuntu Trusty continues to get MySQL 5.6.

The selection of the MySQL version is based on the version
of Ubuntu that is installed.  If the script trovestack is
invoked on Xenial, the version that is chosen is 5.7.  If
it is invoked on Trusty, then version 5.6 is chosen.

The only thing that is eliminated is the dubious combination
of MySQL 5.6 on Ubuntu Xenial.  This combination is probably
not supported by Ubuntu as it is down level from their
standard offering is probably not tested anywhere.

Note Xenial does not provide the 5.6 version of mysql.  This
was accomplished by initializing the Apt repo with the
Trusty software repository.

The size of the root file system is increased from 3 to 4 GBs
as the Mysql Xenial image does not fit in 3 GBs. This has an
impact on the flavors that are used by Trove for testing as the
name of the flavor includes the size of the root file system.

This is turn caused a change to each of the db specific test
config files as the trove falvors are referenced in them.

Change-Id: I4f4e497208b8f4728580e48239a8ae208e0a96dd

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-18 06:05:42.000000000', 'message': 'Generalize DB conf group copying

The direct access of conf.* names in _get_db_conf() method
is an inappropriate usage of oslo.config [1].   Hardcoding
these names prevents oslo.db from being able to easily
rename or deprecate options, as well as to be able to
add new database options, such as those which apply
to new performance tuning or monitoring techniques.
Retrieve values from the config object generically so
that these names remain local to oslo.db. This usage has
been supported in oslo.db enginefacade from its inception [2]
as multiple projects were already doing it for LegacyEngineFacade.

This patch is a copy of below nova change:
I22f8a19009408fb1f1587bf399e6aee3467c8bc6

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-July/119846.html
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/master/oslo_db/tests/sqlalchemy/test_enginefacade.py#L2140

Change-Id: Ie1f4a8e02ff64be2125443ddcd9b95e4f42f593d

commit_message:
Generalize DB conf group copying

The direct access of conf.* names in _get_db_conf() method
is an inappropriate usage of oslo.config [1].   Hardcoding
these names prevents oslo.db from being able to easily
rename or deprecate options, as well as to be able to
add new database options, such as those which apply
to new performance tuning or monitoring techniques.
Retrieve values from the config object generically so
that these names remain local to oslo.db. This usage has
been supported in oslo.db enginefacade from its inception [2]
as multiple projects were already doing it for LegacyEngineFacade.

This patch is a copy of below nova change:
I22f8a19009408fb1f1587bf399e6aee3467c8bc6

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-July/119846.html
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/master/oslo_db/tests/sqlalchemy/test_enginefacade.py#L2140

Change-Id: Ie1f4a8e02ff64be2125443ddcd9b95e4f42f593d

commit_message:
[WIP] Add parameter 'host' to images API

The images API is designed for pull/delete image of individual
host. This patch adds a 'host' parameter to the image.

Implements: blueprint rework-image-api

commit_message:
Add overcloud update converge tasks.

After merging [0] it will be needed an
'overcloud update converge' command to remove
no-ops set during 'update prepare'.

This patch includes all the tasks and templates
to run it.

[0] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/558536/

Change-Id: Ibfc52bc2338dca9c4be2f78e381d90b28626a833
(cherry picked from commit 6dcd6320d93b287aae03fcf6aa7e83ff0f83ecdc)

commit_message:
Remove CephAnsiblePlaybook parameter reset from ceph-ansible env files

With the changes in environments/lifecycle to set/reset the default
CephAnsiblePlaybook value, we do not need to have it in the
ceph-ansible environment files anymore.

Closes-Bug: 1772650
Change-Id: I3004feda52cd03f982c359a027e68514c25ca893

commit_message:
Do not clean up nodes after the deployment has started

If something fails during provisioning, we need to leave the node
intact for debugging. The undeploy command should be used to clean up.

Change-Id: If4bbeceb0307a4df07dbae912db1d7f69c94e3c5

commit_message:
Activate another set of healthchecks

In previous patches link to appropriate scripts were not added.
This patch adds links related to following already merged patches:
 - I757d53189f5819bb3a0e7bebe277353f3460738d
 - I4a193d7ce1c455da2865498470ed3b98160df112
 - Ie8eaab9919bde61793a3310328ee9f117c4e58da
 - Ief543580e6b717bb9dba62b19ffe12aff5395ff9

This patch also adds exec permission to some of the healthchecks
added in above patches.

Change-Id: Id5dc7d169301e45cb0abab7cecae67457db9fd96
(cherry picked from commit e85b982507ec203304b609a5b27434a0aef77919)

[{'account_id': 28165, 'date': '2018-05-26 17:35:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-05-26 17:36:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 28165, 'date': '2018-05-28 17:52:19.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

duplicate with https://review.openstack.org/570658'}]

commit_message:
Add healthcheck script for neutron-sriov-agent

This patch adds script for docker health check of neutron-sriov-agent service.
The script checks existance of service with opened connections to RabbitMQ.

Change-Id: Ief543580e6b717bb9dba62b19ffe12aff5395ff9
(cherry picked from commit 4c45ba2690f89c3ef7295254841a577dab65409d)

commit_message:
Add and fix healthcheck scripts for Octavia services

 - adds script for docker health check of octavia-api service
 - fix the check method for octavia-health-manager service
 - fix the check method for octavia-housekeeping service

Add healthcheck script for ceilometer-agent-compute

This patch adds script for docker health check of ceilometer-agent-compute
service. The script checks existance of service with opened connections
to RabbitMQ.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-28 09:21:44.000000000', 'message': 'Increase services project secgroup-rules quotas when deploying Octavia

This patch is a followup to I6b87b147d301dea3251fe4509b04cd4b9b27ddba,
which lacked the secgroup-rules quota.

The reasoning is the same:
Octavia currently launches load balancer VMs in the services tenant
which has very low quotas by default. This patch increases the values
through the API for the services project to permit lots of load
balancers.

Closes Bug: #1769896

Change-Id: I8ad5175f7ca79939725a0c2342378a052b5c6bd2
'}]
commit_message:
Increase services project secgroup-rules quotas when deploying Octavia

This patch is a followup to I6b87b147d301dea3251fe4509b04cd4b9b27ddba,
which lacked the secgroup-rules quota.

The reasoning is the same:
Octavia currently launches load balancer VMs in the services tenant
which has very low quotas by default. This patch increases the values
through the API for the services project to permit lots of load
balancers.

Closes Bug: #1769896

Change-Id: I8ad5175f7ca79939725a0c2342378a052b5c6bd2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-23 13:33:49.000000000', 'message': "Remove ceph-osd from the list of packages updated by CephExternal

During minor updates, puppet is dealing with packages update and
trying to install 'ceph-osd' on the nodes where CephExternal service
is enabled, see [1].

This change is *not* proposed for master (currently tracking Rocky)
because support for puppet-ceph is removed in Rocky, see [2]. Instead
will be backported into Pike, Ocata and Newton.

1. https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1572830
2. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/548562/

Change-Id: I765bd4c4f630f97fdb4d6d4207dd5c8e0b82922c
(cherry picked from commit f24523a0bc952ad1464a70e50a42ea257adaeacb)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove ceph-osd from the list of packages updated by CephExternal

During minor updates, puppet is dealing with packages update and
trying to install 'ceph-osd' on the nodes where CephExternal service
is enabled, see [1].

This change is *not* proposed for master (currently tracking Rocky)
because support for puppet-ceph is removed in Rocky, see [2]. Instead
will be backported into Pike, Ocata and Newton.

1. https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1572830
2. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/548562/

Change-Id: I765bd4c4f630f97fdb4d6d4207dd5c8e0b82922c
(cherry picked from commit f24523a0bc952ad1464a70e50a42ea257adaeacb)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:
Avoid py3 dependency on py2

The latest cmd2 is built only for python3. Let's fix the latest
available py2 version in requirements on python2.

Change-Id: I8103937a23400c173c2b2bac0b43e104589d9ba7
Signed-off-by: Lukáš Doktor <ldoktor@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-25 00:00:41.000000000', 'message': 'WIP lowercase any hostname comparisons in bootstrap_* scripts

If you deploy a stack with mixed-case hostnames things will break
because no task that is supposed to run on boostrap nodes will run
due to the following code:
HOSTNAME=$(/bin/hostname -s)
SERVICE_NODEID=$(/bin/hiera -c /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml
"${SERVICE_NAME}_short_bootstrap_node_name")
if [[ "$HOSTNAME" == "$SERVICE_NODEID" ]]; then
...

The hiera key might contain mixed-case letters whereas the hostname
won't and the end result is going to be that no bootstrap tasks
will run on any nodes and, amongst other things, no database tables
will be created, making all services unusable.

Change-Id: Ie240b8a4217827dd8ade82479a828817d63143ba
Related-Bug: #1773219
'}, {'created': '2018-05-25 16:26:02.000000000', 'message': 'WIP lowercase any hostname comparisons in bootstrap_* scripts

If you deploy a stack with mixed-case hostnames things will break
because no task that is supposed to run on boostrap nodes will run
due to the following code:
HOSTNAME=$(/bin/hostname -s)
SERVICE_NODEID=$(/bin/hiera -c /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml
"${SERVICE_NAME}_short_bootstrap_node_name")
if [[ "$HOSTNAME" == "$SERVICE_NODEID" ]]; then
...

The hiera key might contain mixed-case letters whereas the hostname
won't and the end result is going to be that no bootstrap tasks
will run on any nodes and, amongst other things, no database tables
will be created, making all services unusable.

Since we use bash explicitely we can leverage the ${var,,} expression
for this.

Change-Id: Ie240b8a4217827dd8ade82479a828817d63143ba
Related-Bug: #1773219

commit_message:
Lowercase any hostname comparisons in bootstrap_* scripts

If you deploy a stack with mixed-case hostnames things will break
because no task that is supposed to run on boostrap nodes will run
due to the following code:
HOSTNAME=$(/bin/hostname -s)
SERVICE_NODEID=$(/bin/hiera -c /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml
"${SERVICE_NAME}_short_bootstrap_node_name")
if [[ "$HOSTNAME" == "$SERVICE_NODEID" ]]; then
...

The hiera key might contain mixed-case letters whereas the hostname
won't and the end result is going to be that no bootstrap tasks
will run on any nodes and, amongst other things, no database tables
will be created, making all services unusable.

Since we use bash explicitely we can leverage the ${var,,} expression
for this.

Change-Id: Ie240b8a4217827dd8ade82479a828817d63143ba
Related-Bug: #1773219

commit_message:
Add Zuulv3 jobs for puppet functional testing

We need to abandon rspec as a functional testing framework. It
constantly breaks as ruby gems change their dependencies, no one likes
to deal with it and it did not help bring new people from the puppet
community to help maintain the modules. This patch adds a Zuulv3-native
job that can act as a framework for the future of puppet functional
testing. Puppet modules will need to have the files
tests/scenarios/*/{manifest.pp,tests.sh} in order to use this.
Eventually this should replace the legacy-puppet-beaker jobs.

Change-Id: Ic47e93fb091a9cdc876981674cff6b452a1afe87

commit_message:
[elasticsearch] Change ES_HEAP_SIZE  to ES_JAVA_OPTS.

After enabling the elasticsearch debian/ubuntu
images the container doesn't starts with ELK 5.4.1
as ES_HEAP_SIZE has been deprecated.

We should use ES_JAVA_OPTS with the -Xms/Xmx options instead.

Closes-Bug: #1772482

Change-Id: I9b368468d41421d679a9c4ad6fdf595863de7a1a
Signed-off-by: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@linaro.org>
(cherry picked from commit a9693b85ac9e60e812a87c21e9b1b55ce01d4180)

commit_message:
Fix MariaDB bootstrap error

grep returns exitcode 1 when no match is found.
Since `set -o errexit` is done in base/start.sh, we need to get rid of grep.

Change-Id: I909cf181c677f61fd76a7128027f89afa5eeac7b
Closes-Bug: 1772442

commit_message:
Follow up to power fault recovery db tests

This is a follow up to address comments about tests left at [1].

By default the test node created by db_utils.get_test_node() will
have a None fault value, so it is unnecessary to assign a None
before tests.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/555708

Change-Id: Ib4786670a06d1257c71ec95d587effcaebc68157
Story: #1596107
Task: #10469

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-10 11:49:34.000000000', 'message': 'Gate fix: Cap hacking to avoid gate failure

hacking is not capped in g-r and it is in
blacklist for requirement as hacking new version
can break the gate jobs.

Hacking can break gate jobs because of various
reasons:
- There might be new rule addition in hacking
- Some rules becomes default from non-default
- Updates in pycodestyle etc

That was the main reason it was not added in g-r
auto sync also. Most of the project maintained the
compatible and cap the hacking version in
test-requirements.txt and update to new version when
project is ready. Bumping new version might need code
fix also on project side depends on what new in that
version.

If project does not have cap the hacking version then,
there is possibility of gate failure whenever new hacking
version is released by QA team.

Example of such failure in recent release of hacking 1.1.0
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-May/130282.html

Change-Id: I2c84d3368bd6675c28ebba695e0c1afdd2867588
(cherry picked from commit a69ccee2879abe3ac658f3fcbb564b254d84803d)

commit_message:
Gate fix: Cap hacking to avoid gate failure

hacking is not capped in g-r and it is in
blacklist for requirement as hacking new version
can break the gate jobs.

Hacking can break gate jobs because of various
reasons:
- There might be new rule addition in hacking
- Some rules becomes default from non-default
- Updates in pycodestyle etc

That was the main reason it was not added in g-r
auto sync also. Most of the project maintained the
compatible and cap the hacking version in
test-requirements.txt and update to new version when
project is ready. Bumping new version might need code
fix also on project side depends on what new in that
version.

If project does not have cap the hacking version then,
there is possibility of gate failure whenever new hacking
version is released by QA team.

Example of such failure in recent release of hacking 1.1.0
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-May/130282.html

Also includes commit c09634ad80988e960af2bcaca737be3e87ba7592 from
master to ignore W503, otherwise the CI does not pass.

Change-Id: I2c84d3368bd6675c28ebba695e0c1afdd2867588
(cherry picked from commit a69ccee2879abe3ac658f3fcbb564b254d84803d)
(cherry picked from commit c09634ad80988e960af2bcaca737be3e87ba7592)

commit_message:
cli: replace metrics by metric

All cli endpoint takes --metric, expect one. To avoid confusion
allow --metric everywhere.

Change-Id: I443ffaedc53508604a3895819f5dc1b443905bf2

[horizon] change settings prefix for ubuntu/binary

Use /usr/share/openstack-dashboard/openstack_dashboard/local/
instead of site-packages/** for ubuntu/binary installs.

Closes-Bug: #1773105
Signed-off-by: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@linaro.org>

After enabling the elasticsearch debian/ubuntu
images the container doesn't starts with ELK 5.4.1
as ES_HEAP_SIZE has been deprecated.

We should use ES_JAVA_OPTS with the -Xms/Xmx options instead.

Closes-Bug: #1772482

Change-Id: I9b368468d41421d679a9c4ad6fdf595863de7a1a
Signed-off-by: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@linaro.org>
"}]
commit_message:
[elasticsearch] Change ES_HEAP_SIZE  to ES_JAVA_OPTS.

After enabling the elasticsearch debian/ubuntu
images the container doesn't starts with ELK 5.4.1
as ES_HEAP_SIZE has been deprecated.

We should use ES_JAVA_OPTS with the -Xms/Xmx options instead.

Closes-Bug: #1772482

Change-Id: I9b368468d41421d679a9c4ad6fdf595863de7a1a
Signed-off-by: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@linaro.org>

commit_message:
Make add_go_to_flow smart about goto vs. resubmit

If the table_id is greater (or equal) to the destination table,
resubmit should be used instead of goto. This patch enforces
that in add_go_to_table_flow method.

This is needed since the OpenFlow specification allow goto instructions
only to tables with a greater number. See section 5.1 of the
specification[1] for more details.

[1] https://www.opennetworking.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/openflow-spec-v1.3.1.pdf

Change-Id: I6d1995d36bd83a90052ed475d14be93601ca6e98

[{'created': '2018-05-11 09:55:56.000000000', 'message': "Always run mysql init bundle

This init container runs docker-puppet manually and is responsible of
provisioning the mysql users and passwords. This currently doesn't get
ran every time since the configuration stays the same, even if the users
or passwords change (which are gotten from hieradata). Allowing this to
run every time will allow us to change database passwords

Closes-Bug: #1762991
Change-Id: I1f07272499b419079466cf9f395fb04a082099bd
(cherry picked from commit 6c40b1586ab1269e124f0f71d094834137819375)
"}]
commit_message:
Always run mysql init bundle

This init container runs docker-puppet manually and is responsible of
provisioning the mysql users and passwords. This currently doesn't get
ran every time since the configuration stays the same, even if the users
or passwords change (which are gotten from hieradata). Allowing this to
run every time will allow us to change database passwords

Closes-Bug: #1762991
Change-Id: I1f07272499b419079466cf9f395fb04a082099bd
(cherry picked from commit 6c40b1586ab1269e124f0f71d094834137819375)

commit_message:
Use /usr/bin/env python to autodetect python

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/564024/ used
/bin/python as the shebang but this can be different
for different platforms, switch to /usr/bin/env to
handle it.

Also update undercloud_ctlplane_network.py to use
/usr/bin/env for consistency, although this file
is not executable.

Change-Id: Id915ded03ae5a471ffa2dca13e2da90021279f63
